A triangle is made of wood sticks of lengths 8, 15 and 17 inches joined end-to-end. Pieces of the same integral length are cut from each of the sticks so that the three remaining pieces can no longer form a triangle. How many inches are in the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks to make this happen?
inference:
Let the lengths of the three sticks be $a=8$, $b=15$, and $c=17$.
Let $x$ be the length of the piece cut from each stick.
The remaining lengths are $8-x$, $15-x$, and $17-x$.
For the remaining pieces to not form a triangle, the triangle inequality must not hold.
The triangle inequality states that the sum of the lengths of any two sides of a triangle must be greater than the length of the third side.
Case 1: $(8-x) + (15-x) > 17-x$
$23-2x > 17-x$
$6 > x$
Case 2: $(8-x) + (17-x) > 15-x$
$25-2x > 15-x$
$10 > x$
Case 3: $(15-x) + (17-x) > 8-x$
$32-2x > 8-x$
$24 > x$
Combining these inequalities, we get $x<6$.
The possible values for $x$ are integers.
If $x = 1$, then the lengths of the remaining pieces are 7, 14, 16.
The triangle inequality is satisfied:
7+14 > 16, 7+16 > 14, 14+16 > 7
If $x = 2$, then the lengths of the remaining pieces are 6, 13, 15.
The triangle inequality is satisfied:
6+13 > 15, 6+15 > 13, 13+15 > 6
If $x = 3$, then the lengths of the remaining pieces are 5, 12, 14.
The triangle inequality is satisfied:
5+12 > 14, 5+14 > 12, 12+14 > 5
If $x = 4$, then the lengths of the remaining pieces are 4, 11, 13.
The triangle inequality is satisfied:
4+11 > 13, 4+13 > 11, 11+13 > 4
If $x = 5$, then the lengths of the remaining pieces are 3, 10, 12.
The triangle inequality is satisfied:
3+10 > 12, 3+12 > 10, 10+12 > 3
The smallest value of $x$ that makes the remaining pieces not form a triangle is when $x=6$.
For $x=6$, the remaining lengths are 2, 9, 11.
2+9 = 11, so the triangle inequality is not satisfied.
Final Answer: $\boxed{6}$
ground_truth: Our current triangle lengths are 8, 15, and 17. Let us say that $x$ is the length of the piece that we cut from each of the three sticks. Then, our lengths will be $8 - x,$ $15 - x,$ and $17 - x.$ These lengths will no longer form a triangle when the two shorter lengths added together is shorter than or equal to the longest length. In other words, $(8 - x) + (15 - x) \leq (17 - x).$ Then, we have $23 - 2x \leq 17 - x,$ so $6 \leq x.$ Therefore, the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks is $\boxed{6}$ inches.
